The convolution of two even functions is also even.

type:
∀ {𝕜 : Type u𝕜} {G : Type uG} {E : Type uE} {E' : Type uE'} {F : Type uF} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup E'] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F] {f : G → E} {g : G → E'} {x : G}
  [inst_3 : NontriviallyNormedField 𝕜] [inst_4 : NormedSpace 𝕜 E] [inst_5 : NormedSpace 𝕜 E'] [inst_6 : NormedSpace 𝕜 F]
  (L : E →L[𝕜] E' →L[𝕜] F) [inst_7 : MeasurableSpace G] {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure G} [inst_8 : NormedSpace ℝ F]
  [inst_9 : AddCommGroup G] [inst_10 : MeasureTheory.Measure.IsAddLeftInvariant μ]
  [inst_11 : MeasureTheory.Measure.IsNegInvariant μ] [inst_12 : MeasurableNeg G] [inst_13 : MeasurableAdd G],
  (∀ᵐ (x : G) ∂μ, f (-x) = f x) → (∀ᵐ (x : G) ∂μ, g (-x) = g x) → convolution f g L (-x) = convolution f g L x
name: convolution_neg_of_neg_eq
docString: The convolution of two even functions is also even.

For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), Even (n * (n - 1))
name: Nat.even_mul_self_pred
docString: For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n - 1` is an even number. In mathematical terms, this theorem can be written as: "∀ n ∈ ℕ, n*(n - 1) is even." Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as twice another number, in this case, n*(n - 1) = 2*r for some `r`.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), Even (n * (n - 1))
name: Nat.even_mul_self_pred
docString: This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n - 1` is an even number. In mathematical terms, this theorem can be written as: "∀ n ∈ ℕ, n*(n - 1) is even." Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as twice another number, in this case, n*(n - 1) = 2*r for some `r`.

Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same multiples.

name: Nat.dvd_right_iff_eq
docString: Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same multiples.

The sum of two natural numbers is even if and only if both numbers are even or both are odd.

type: ∀ {m n : ℕ}, Even (m + n) ↔ (Even m ↔ Even n)
name: Nat.even_add
docString: The sum of two natural numbers is even if and only if both numbers are even or both are odd.

This theorem states that for all natural numbers `m` and `n`, the sum `m + n` is even if and only if `m` and `n` are both even or both odd. In other words, the parity of the sum of two natural numbers is the same as the parity of the individual numbers. Here, `Even` is a property of a number that is defined to be true if the number can be expressed as the sum of two equal numbers.

type: ∀ {m n : ℕ}, Even (m + n) ↔ (Even m ↔ Even n)
name: Nat.even_add
docString: This theorem states that for all natural numbers `m` and `n`, the sum `m + n` is even if and only if `m` and `n` are both even or both odd. In other words, the parity of the sum of two natural numbers is the same as the parity of the individual numbers. Here, `Even` is a property of a number that is defined to be true if the number can be expressed as the sum of two equal numbers.

The set of natural numbers that are sums of two squares is closed under multiplication.

type: ∀ {a b x y u v : ℕ}, a = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 → b = u ^ 2 + v ^ 2 → ∃ r s, a * b = r ^ 2 + s ^ 2
name: Nat.sq_add_sq_mul
docString: The set of natural numbers that are sums of two squares is closed under multiplication.

Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same divisors.

name: Nat.dvd_left_iff_eq
docString: Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same divisors.

The product of two natural numbers is greater than 1 if and only if
at least one of them is greater than 1 and both are positive.

name: Nat.one_lt_mul_iff
docString:
The product of two natural numbers is greater than 1 if and only if
at least one of them is greater than 1 and both are positive.

A product of finite numbers is still finite

type:
∀ {ι : Type u_1} {R : Type u_8} [inst : CommMonoidWithZero R] [inst_1 : NoZeroDivisors R] [inst_2 : Nontrivial R]
  [inst_3 : DecidableEq R] [inst_4 : LT R] {s : Finset ι} {f : ι → WithTop R},
  (∀ i ∈ s, f i ≠ ⊤) → (Finset.prod s fun i => f i) < ⊤
name: WithTop.prod_lt_top
docString: A product of finite numbers is still finite

The product of two positive elements is positive.

type: ∀ {α : Type u} [self : StrictOrderedRing α] (a b : α), 0 < a → 0 < b → 0 < a * b
name: StrictOrderedRing.mul_pos
docString: The product of two positive elements is positive.

Every x greater than or equal to 1 is between two successive
natural-number powers of every y greater than one.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : LinearOrderedSemiring α] [inst_1 : Archimedean α] [inst_2 : ExistsAddOfLE α] {x y : α},
  1 ≤ x → 1 < y → ∃ n, y ^ n ≤ x ∧ x < y ^ (n + 1)
name: exists_nat_pow_near
docString:
Every x greater than or equal to 1 is between two successive
natural-number powers of every y greater than one.

The product of a list of positive natural numbers is positive,
and likewise for any nontrivial ordered semiring.

type: ∀ {R : Type u_8} [inst : StrictOrderedSemiring R] (l : List R), (∀ a ∈ l, 0 < a) → 0 < List.prod l
name: List.prod_pos
docString:
The product of a list of positive natural numbers is positive,
and likewise for any nontrivial ordered semiring.

The sequence of natural numbers some 0, some 1, ...

type: Stream'.Seq ℕ
name: Stream'.Seq.nats
docString: The sequence of natural numbers some 0, some 1, ...

Subsequent Fibonacci numbers are coprime,
see https://proofwiki.org/wiki/Consecutive_Fibonacci_Numbers_are_Coprime

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), Nat.Coprime (Nat.fib n) (Nat.fib (n + 1))
name: Nat.fib_coprime_fib_succ
docString:
Subsequent Fibonacci numbers are coprime,
see https://proofwiki.org/wiki/Consecutive_Fibonacci_Numbers_are_Coprime

If `m` and `n` are natural numbers, then the natural number `m^n` is even
if and only if `m` is even and `n` is positive.

type: ∀ {m n : ℕ}, Even (m ^ n) ↔ Even m ∧ n ≠ 0
name: Nat.even_pow
docString:
If `m` and `n` are natural numbers, then the natural number `m^n` is even
if and only if `m` is even and `n` is positive.

The proposition that a sequence indexed by integers is a divisibility sequence.

type: {R : Type u} → [inst : CommRing R] → (ℤ → R) → Prop
name: IsDivSequence
docString: The proposition that a sequence indexed by integers is a divisibility sequence.

The finite field `F` has even cardinality iff it has characteristic `2`.

type: ∀ {F : Type u_3} [inst : Field F] [inst_1 : Fintype F], ringChar F = 2 ↔ Fintype.card F % 2 = 0
name: FiniteField.even_card_iff_char_two
docString: The finite field `F` has even cardinality iff it has characteristic `2`.

A sum of finite numbers is still finite

type: ∀ {α : Type u_1} {s : Finset α} {f : α → ENNReal}, (∀ a ∈ s, f a ≠ ⊤) → (Finset.sum s fun a => f a) < ⊤
name: ENNReal.sum_lt_top
docString: A sum of finite numbers is still finite

The product of two finite adèles is a finite adèle.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} {K : Type u_2} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] [inst_2 : IsDedekindDomain R]
  [inst_3 : Field K] [inst_4 : Algebra R K] [inst_5 : IsFractionRing R K]
  {x y : DedekindDomain.ProdAdicCompletions R K},
  DedekindDomain.ProdAdicCompletions.IsFiniteAdele x →
    DedekindDomain.ProdAdicCompletions.IsFiniteAdele y → DedekindDomain.ProdAdicCompletions.IsFiniteAdele (x * y)
name: DedekindDomain.ProdAdicCompletions.IsFiniteAdele.mul
docString: The product of two finite adèles is a finite adèle.

Two pnats are coprime if their gcd is 1.

type: ℕ+ → ℕ+ → Prop
name: PNat.Coprime
docString: Two pnats are coprime if their gcd is 1.

The clifford algebra is graded by the even and odd parts.

type:
{R : Type u_1} →
  {M : Type u_2} →
    [inst : CommRing R] →
      [inst_1 : AddCommGroup M] →
        [inst_2 : Module R M] → (Q : QuadraticForm R M) → GradedAlgebra (CliffordAlgebra.evenOdd Q)
name: CliffordAlgebra.gradedAlgebra
docString: The clifford algebra is graded by the even and odd parts.

the condition on the two integers

type: ∀ {n : ℤ} (self : CochainComplex.HomComplex.Triplet n), self.p + n = self.q
name: CochainComplex.HomComplex.Triplet.hpq
docString: the condition on the two integers

The sum of two finite adèles is a finite adèle.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} {K : Type u_2} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] [inst_2 : IsDedekindDomain R]
  [inst_3 : Field K] [inst_4 : Algebra R K] [inst_5 : IsFractionRing R K]
  {x y : DedekindDomain.ProdAdicCompletions R K},
  DedekindDomain.ProdAdicCompletions.IsFiniteAdele x →
    DedekindDomain.ProdAdicCompletions.IsFiniteAdele y → DedekindDomain.ProdAdicCompletions.IsFiniteAdele (x + y)
name: DedekindDomain.ProdAdicCompletions.IsFiniteAdele.add
docString: The sum of two finite adèles is a finite adèle.
